text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I'm Ann Reardon 
and in this episode i thought we would debunk

some of the "healthy" dessert recipes 
that are on TikTok and YouTube! I get

so many requests for healthy dessert recipes 
and there's so much conflicting information

out there for people so i thought we would look 
at some of them and have a look specifically at

the sugars and sugar alternatives that they're 
using in the recipes so we can talk through

what's what and explain what's going on. Firstly 
let's start with agave nectar this seemed like

it was everywhere a few years ago every healthy 
dessert recipe had it in ... two tablespoons of

agave nectar ... one and a half cups agave nectar 
in this ... add two tablespoons of agave nectar.

So why was everybody using agave nectar what were 
the claims about it? Agave nectar is low glycemic

and really easy to use ... the high fructose 
content in agave can have some undesirable health

effects ... one of the biggest reasons that i'm 
a fan of agave syrup is simply the fact that it's

right in the sweet spot when it comes to the 
glycemic index ... agave nectar is probably

the least healthy most health-washed sweetener on 
the planet. So this is why it's confusing some say

it's really good others say it's terrible which is 
it? Well let's break down those claims first. The

first one said that it's low glycemic index or 
low GI if you've never heard of glycemic index

don't worry you'll be an expert after the next 
couple of minutes. What the glycemic index is

is they give a group of people 50 grams of 
carbohydrate from one source so in this case 50

grams of carbohydrate from agave nectar. They then 
measure their blood glucose reading over the next

two hours so they can graph how quickly it goes up 
or how slowly it goes up and then comes back down.

They then compare that graph to the graph the same 
people get when they're given 50 grams of straight

glucose. Now glucose is a very simple form of 
sugar let's say for example sake that this blue

Lego brick is glucose when glucose is eaten it 
goes into the stomach and then into the intestine

where it doesn't need digesting or breaking down 
it's already in a very simple form we can't break

that down anymore, so now it's going to go into 
the bloodstream where it can be used by the body

for energy because we use glucose in our cells for 
all sorts of processes. So that's the fastest way

to get your blood glucose up is to eat straight 
plain glucose because it goes directly into your

bloodstream so that gets the glycemic index of 100 
and everything else is scored compared to that on

a comparison to straight glucose. So what would 
happen if we ate agave nectar and what happens

if we eat straight sugar? Well to show you a 
comparison i've put a blood glucose continuous

monitor into my arm which i thought would really 
really hurt but it didn't hurt at all and i can't

even tell it's there but the advantage of that 
that means i can just use an app on my phone

and when i want to know my blood glucose reading 
i can just scan the little sensor on my arm and

it will tell you my blood glucose reading so that 
i don't have to continually do finger prick tests

over the two hours to get the graph for you 😊 So 
i'll start with the agave nectar ... so this is 20

grams of carbohydrate from the 
agave nectar so i'm gonna eat this

and then measure my blood glucose over the 
next two hours so i can show you the graph

of what happens and then i'll do the same 
with sugar and we'll have a chat about it.

Here is my blood glucose over two hours for agave 
nectar and you can see that it's hardly gone up

at all so why is that, why did my blood glucose 
not just shoot right up when i ate that really

sweet sugary substance? That's because it is low 
GI the reason it's low GI is if we look at agave

nectar it's made up the majority of it of fructose 
not glucose so if glucose is this blue brick

fructose is going to be this red brick they're 
very very very similar in structure to each other

but they're not the same. So let's say that we 
eat this it goes into our stomach and then our

intestines it doesn't need breaking down because 
it's already a simple sugar it can get absorbed

straight away into the bloodstream and now we've 
got lots of fructose in our bloodstream but it's

not glucose so the glucose monitor is only telling 
us how much glucose is in our bloodstream so

that's not going to show up at all because it's 
fructose. Now our cells can't just use fructose

just like that so that means it's got to go to 
the liver for processing to make it into something

useful. In the liver it can get converted into 
glucose so that we can use it or if you have a

large amount and i'm meaning lots of it in studies 
where they gave people humans 25% of their calorie

intake from fructose then you will convert it 
into fat so triglycerides and cholesterol and

that is going to up those levels in your blood and 
that then increases your risk of heart attack and

that is not a good thing. So despite the fact that 
it is low GI because it doesn't have much straight

glucose in it it's not ideal because it's so high 
in fructose and high amounts of fructose are not

good for us because they've got to be processed in 
the liver. A little bit of fructose is fine so if

you're having fructose for example in your fruit 
totally fine but if you're starting to concentrate

that down and have huge sources of fructose like 
in high fructose corn syrup in soft drinks in this

sort of thing that's just going to give us way 
too much and it's not going to be good for us.

So how does that compare to straight sugar? Well 
i'm going to eat 20 grams of straight sugar for

you so that we can then see exactly what that's 
like and what that does to my blood sugars...

I can think of so many more enjoyable ways 
to have sugar than eating straight sugar 😬

the things i do for you you!
You can see on this graph my blood sugar spiked

up fairly quickly and then also dropped back down 
very quickly the rapid rise meant that we released

lots of insulin into the blood to store all 
that glucose and then it dropped back down.

So what is normal sugar made of is that 
made of glucose or is that made of fructose?

Well it's actually made of sucrose and sucrose 
is a glucose and a fructose joined together

so what happens when you eat that is it goes 
into your stomach and then into your intestine

and there's enzymes in your intestine that break 
that down, split it up into fructose and glucose.

That then gets absorbed and the glucose can 
be used straight away or stored as glycogen

and the fructose of course has to go to the liver 
for processing. The other thing a lot of people

don't understand about the glycemic index they 
go oh low glycemic index that means it's healthy

or that means it's good but there's other things 
you have to consider which is you don't usually

eat agave nectar or plain sugar just on its own 
... well that guy does ... and i just did and

you would if you had it in your coffee but apart 
from that it's usually mixed in with other things.

I'm going to choose one of the healthy recipes 
that has virtually no other carbs in it apart

from the agave nectar and i'm going to make it 
once using agave nectar and once using sugar

and then i'm going to eat the same amount of each 
one and i'm going to wait two hours in between so

that i can test the blood glucose levels and show 
you what happens. This is the blood glucose graft

for when i had the agave nectar and you can see 
that it went up a little bit but hardly at all

which is to be expected because this is low GI 
there was hardly any other carbs in the recipe

so that's what you'd think would happen. Next if 
I eat the same amount for the one with sugar in it

this is what happens ... see how there's no 
massive spike it goes up slightly a little bit

more than the agave nectar one but not a lot it's 
going up slowly. So why is that? Well there's two

reasons one is the glycemic load which is how much 
of it are you eating so there's not as much in

the piece of that that i had as there was when i 
just ate 20 grams of straight sugar, the other is

there's other ingredients in there for example the 
nuts they were very high in fat and fat slows down

food getting out of your stomach it sits in your 
stomach for quite a bit longer which is going

to slow down that digestion and release all the 
sugars into your bloodstream so the combination

of different foods can really affect what the 
overall glycemic effect of what you eat is.

So should you swap all your white sugar in baking 
for agave nectar would that be healthier for you?

No if you're still eating the same amount of it 
for you it's not healthier for you it's got to go

to your liver for processing and if you're having 
a large amount of it it is not going to be good

for you ... small amount it won't matter which one 
you use large amount you'd actually be better off

with that one. Even the fans of agave nectar have 
now seemed to change their mind ... I'm a fan of

agave syrup it is quite honestly it's kind of a 
sham they market it as low glycemic index that

people buy it thinking it's healthy but it will 
make you a lot more fat i'm just honestly it

just has that effect so try to avoid that ... 
I used to use a lot of agave because i really

like the flavor and yes it's low on the glycemic 
index but it turns out that agave nectar has a

ton of fructose in it actually almost the same 
amount of fructose that light refined sugar has.

Actually agave nectar has a lot more fructose in 
it than normal sugar does if we look at the graph

of them side by side white sugar is half glucose 
half fructose. High fructose corn syrup has a

little bit less glucose and a bit more fructose 
and agave nectar has even less glucose and even

more fructose. Wouldn't it be great if someone 
could invent a food that didn't have the fructose

it just had the glucose but it had it in a way 
that it was low GI that'd be awesome 🧐... oh

hang on a minute that already exists in starchy 
foods you have all the glucose molecules joined

together. Now not all starchy foods are low GI 
some are high GI they're just easy to break down

but others are low GI. Things like pasta 
rice noodles your really grainy breads

they have plenty of starch and they're low GI and 
that's a good way to get that into your body far

better than adding heaps of your agave nectar or 
sugar into your food. Okay next ... i am obsessed

with coconut sugar ... two tablespoons coconut 
sugar ... start with some coconut sugar ... then

you'll add some coconut sugar ... coconut sugar 
... let's chop the differences so as you can see

it is unrefined and low glycemic which means that 
it's going to affect your blood sugar levels much

differently than a white refined sugar coconut 
sugar also contains all the minerals that i will

put right here so these are just a few reasons why 
i like to personally use coconut sugar over white

sugar. Has a huge component to it that i am a big 
big fan of and that is the fact that coconut sugar

contains something called inulin. Inulin is what 
is called a prebiotic fiber. If i have to pick

my favorite of all these for health benefits i 
would say coconut nectar the glycemic index of

coconut nectar is about 35 it's very natural it's 
very like organic in its own state it's got raw

enzymes and minerals so it actually has a lot of 
great health benefits. This stuff sounds amazing

hey 🧐Well let's look at all of those claims ... 
firstly low GI it can have a slightly lower GI

than normal sugar if it has fiber in it but 
depending how much it's processed it may not have

hardly any fiber in it at all and therefore its 
GI is very similar to sugar. So what's it actually

made of what is in your coconut syrup or your 
coconut sugar well it is made of sucrose surprise

surprise exactly the same as normal sugar which 
is a glucose and a fructose joined together and

it also has some free already broken up glucose 
and fructose in there so all together it is

sugar ... it says it on the label coconut sugar 
that's what it is it's nothing magical about it.

The other claims there were ... coconut 
sugar contains something called inulin

inulin is what is called a prebiotic fiber ... 
if you had 50 grams of this in a day which i

would not recommend you'd get less inulin 
from it than you would if you ate a banana

so eat some fruit and veg as your source of inulin 
not coconut sugar shouldn't be promoted as a good

source of that. Now the other thing that a lot of 
people said was that it had lots of minerals in it

so let's take a look at that one coconut sugar 
also contains all the minerals that i will put

right here ... if you were to eat four teaspoons 
of your coconut nectar or your coconut sugar

you'd get the same amount of iron as you would get 
from one tiny 10 gram bite of steak and the iron

in the steak would be better absorbed because it's 
an easier form of iron for your body to absorb

and use. So is it a good source of iron no does 
it have iron in it yes but so does normal sugar i

could start labeling normal sugar with it contains 
iron it contains zinc it's got minerals in it

but it's not a good 'source' of the minerals it's 
got so much sugar in there that it's called empty

calories because you'd have to eat so much of it 
to get these things that you would be sick if you

ate that much of it. As for the other claims of 
it being 'natural' and 'raw' it's very natural

those two things don't have any regulation in the 
food law so if i'm trying to sell sugar i can say

that this sugar is raw and it's natural to boot. 
It's sugar! If you really like the taste of it you

could swap some of it it's no worse for you than 
normal sugar but it's no better for you either.

All right before i get on to the next one 
let me tell you about today's sponsor KiwiCo.

We have been using KiwiCo crates for 
years, i really really like this company

love their products. Last month i got this working 
safe which shows you how the locking mechanism

works. They have different categories of crates 
to cater for all the different ages from toddlers

right through to adults and he is always 
excited when a new one arrives. Inside a

super cool project designed to encourage kids to

engineering arts and maths and the instructions 
are kid-friendly and the magazine always has extra

content about the theme of that box so they've 
been just great in home learning. Everything

you need to make the project is included in 
the box so you don't need to go to the shops.

How cool is that? You can click on the link in the 
description below to get 50% off your first KiwiCo

crate they really are great so make sure you check 
those out. Okay now moving on to Manuka honey this

one has so many health claims out there ... this 
is Manuka honey ... Manuka honey also known as

super honey ... it'll help your immune system ... 
i like to take a teaspoon a day and i really have

seen improvement in my life ... number three it 
won't spike your blood sugar as quickly ... also

antiviral and anti-inflammatory ... i would 
go for Manuka honey it's a little pricier but

it's almost like you're getting medicine! 😳 First 
of all let's look at the glycemic index for honey

it is very very similar to sugar it's slightly 
lower but not enough that you'd notice if you

are monitoring your blood glucose and no i'm not 
going to eat 20 grams of honey to show you the

comparison. Let's talk about what sugars are in 
it it is made up of some glucose and some fructose

and some sucrose which as you now know is a 
glucose and a fructose joined together and some

maltose which is a new one for you it is a glucose 
and a glucose joined together so i'll pop that one

there. So is honey antibacterial should we be 
eating it to kill all the bacteria in our system

well we've got good gut bacteria in there too 
that we don't want to kill so i hope not so where

is this study come from? Well there are lots of 
studies actually that show if you dilute honey to

a dilution of 40% or greater of honey and then you 
put it in a petri dish and you add some bacteria

then after 24 hours certain types of bacteria 
have been killed they're not viable anymore so

yes it does have some antibacterial properties 
and it is being looked at for the use on wounds

and that sort of thing but that's leaving it for 
24 hours in the one spot and that doesn't happen

when we're eating it. Prebiotic fibre does it 
have that in it yes it does but it's a very

small amount you'd be better off getting it from 
other foods that are going to give you lots of

fiber and be really good for your gut i wouldn't 
eat honey to try and improve your gut bacteria

if you are swapping say sugar in your tea for 
honey it is marginally better for you but even

better would be to get rid of the sugar from 
the tea all together. Okay moving on to the

ever popular maple syrup these are super healthy 
delicious and easy to make they make for the

perfect summer dessert two tablespoons of pure 
maple syrup ... maple syrup one third cup maple

syrup maple syrup maple syrup maple syrup maple 
syrup has a very similar glycemic index to normal

sugar so you're not at an advantage there. The 
types of sugar in it are pretty much the same as

your coconut sugar it's mainly sucrose so mainly 
the same as normal white sugar with a little bit

of free fructose and glucose in there as well so 
it is going to as you know by now just going to go

into your bloodstream as fructose and glucose it 
is still sugar and yes it has a tiny bit of starch

in there a tiny bit of some minerals in there but 
is that a good source of those things no it's not

is swapping all your sugar for one of these sugar 
alternatives a good idea? Not really they're

still just sugar that's not going to make a huge 
difference to your diet or your health or anything

for that matter. Now i've had so many requests 
from people saying can you do a healthy dessert

recipe and my answer is always eat some fruit 🍏eat 
a fruit salad. Cakes and biscuits and chocolates

and things that we make on the channel are treats 
they're for special occasions they are not healthy

they are not good for you. Fruits and vegetables 
and whole grains cereals they're good for you eat

lots of those things. Now i can't finish this 
video without talking about straight sugar the

elephant in the room isn't sugar bad for you 
shouldn't we be avoiding it at all costs? Well

let's have a look at some of the claims on 
straight sugar ... cane sugar you guys gotta

stay away from the stuff and i don't care if 
it's cane sugar sugar in the raw turbinado sugar,

organic cane sugar sugar is the devil you guys. 
What makes you sick and overweight it's not fat

the answer is sugar and the average American 
consumes about 152 pounds of sugar a year ... and

there have been so many documentaries and news 
programs all about sugar, sugar, sugar, sugar,

sugar so that everyone is convinced at the moment 
that sugar is bad everything else is fine we can

eat as much fat and everything else as we want 
it's just sugar sugar is the problem which we

like to do that as humans just make it simple 
just one little thing don't tell me i have to

eat well and exercise i don't want that i 
just want to take one thing out of my diet

and replace it with something else that's just 
as sugary and then i'll be all good but it's not

how it works. Interestingly in regards to just 
trying to reduce sugar if you look in Australia

from 1980 until 2003 as Australia as a whole 
our total sugar consumption from all types of

sugar not just from straight sugar declined 16% 
... our obesity rate went up threefold! So just

reducing sugar on its own is not the solution we 
need to reduce sugar and fatty foods and increase

the amount of healthy whole grain breads and 
cereals fruit and veggie that we're eating.

The number one thing you could do for your 
diet today is making sure you're getting five

proper full serves of vegetables every day 
and i bet that you're not because that's a

lot of vegetables. If you focus on increasing that 
first it helps get everything else into balance.
